Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with severe, life-threatening symptoms of an unknown illness.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I’m reviewing the patient’s chart. It’s Sunday evening—my mother’s name flashes on the screen. I promised her I’d call every week, no matter how busy I was. She worries if I’m late, and I know she’s waiting, probably sitting by the window, phone in hand, eager to hear my voice and my stories from the hospital. But in front of me, a patient gasps for breath, his skin clammy, his symptoms not matching anything I’ve seen before. The nurses look to me for answers, expecting swift, decisive action. My mind races through possible diagnoses, but nothing fits. I feel the weight of my white coat and the stethoscope around my neck, the responsibility pressing down on me. My phone vibrates again—my mother’s gentle persistence. I want to reassure her, to be the attentive daughter she deserves, but I can’t ignore the desperate eyes of the man before me. My heart aches, torn between the comfort of home and the urgency of the ER, caught in the impossible space between daughter and doctor.
